source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: Corrosion exposures were at 360°C and were short term of four-day duration. Concentration of lithium covered the range 0.7 to 3500 ppm and boron was added at 300, 600 and 1200 ppm.
corrosion_data: acceleration observed at >350 ppm Li

evidence_span: Corrosion exposures were at 360°C and were short term of four-day duration. Concentration of lithium covered the range 0.7 to 3500 ppm and boron was added at 300, 600 and 1200 ppm.
corrosion_data: acceleration observed at >60 ppm Li

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4 fuel cladding specimens, $2 . 5 \mathrm { - } \mathsf { c m }$ long and $2 2 \thinspace \mathsf { c m } ^ { 2 }$ in area, were cut from standard cold-worked and stress-relieved tubing $1 . 5 \ \mathrm { c m }$ in diameter and 0.04 cm in wall thickness.
conditions: 360°C, 4 days, LiOH solutions with various lithium concentrations (0.7-3500 ppm) and boric acid additions (300-1200 ppm boron)
corrosion_data: weight gain data shown in Fig. 1

extra_properties.surface_preparation: mechanical polishing and pickling in acid baths

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: Zr-2.5Nb specimens were obtained from CANDU (CANada Deuterium Uranium) pressure tube material, that is, cold-worked and stress-relieved tube $1 0 \ \mathtt { c m }$ in diameter and $\pmb { 0 . 4 \ c m }$ in wall thickness.
conditions: 360°C, 4 days, LiOH solutions with various lithium concentrations (0.7-3500 ppm) and boric acid additions (300-1200 ppm boron)
corrosion_data: weight gain data shown in Fig. 2, oxide spalling observed at high lithium concentrations

extra_properties.surface_preparation: mechanical polishing and pickling in acid baths

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: In separate two-day exposure tests at $3 1 6 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } .$ ,electrochemical potential and polarization measurements were made.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk3

conditions: 360°C, LiOH (3500 ppm Li) + H₃BO₃ (1200 ppm B) solution, 4-day exposure
corrosion_data: weight gain 45 mg dm⁻²

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk6

extra_properties.corrosion_acceleration: occurs at ~60 ppm lithium without H₃BO₃
extra_properties.oxide_behavior: films stay adherent without H₃BO₃ but spallation occurs with H₃BO₃ at high concentrations

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk6

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk9
evidence_span: The spalling of oxide as a fine powder resulting in weight losses is likely the result of a dissolution process

extra_properties.oxide_spalling: fine powder resulting in weight losses

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk9
evidence_span: Unlike Zircaloy-4 fuel cladding, the niobium alloy has a thin beta zirconium layer covering the alpha grains

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk10
evidence_span: In our four-day exposures at 360°C, the harmful effect of LiOH is observed at concentrations >350 ppm lithium for Zircaloy-4 fuel cladding
corrosion_data: weight gain measurements showing harmful effect of LiOH >350 ppm lithium

extra_properties.porosity_characterization: SIMS profiles indicate near-surface concentration of lithium and boron isotopes

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk10
evidence_span: In post-transition type films, the outer oxide layer has both a micro (pore diameter 0.5 to 2 nm) and a meso (pore diameter >2 nm) porosity and the inner layer has only the micro porosity

extra_properties.oxide_layer_structure: outer layer with micro (0.5-2 nm) and meso (>2 nm) porosity, inner layer with micro porosity only

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk10
evidence_span: Corrosion is controlled by oxygen transport through the inner nonporous layers whose thickness is determined by the lithium concentration in the solution

extra_properties.corrosion_mechanism: oxygen transport through inner nonporous layers
extra_properties.lithium_distribution: OLi in outer porous oxide, LiOH in inner nonporous oxide
extra_properties.pore_accessibility: outer oxide accessible to corroding solution, inner oxide not accessible

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk11
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4 were irradiated in BWRs at a temperature near 561 K. Neutron fluences were at various values between 2 and 1.4×10²⁵ n/m² (E > 1 MeV)
conditions: irradiation temperature: 561 K; neutron fluence: 2-1.4×10²⁵ n/m² (E > 1 MeV)
corrosion_data: nodular corrosion eliminated at 793 K steam; uniform corrosion increased at 589 K water and 673 K steam

extra_properties.irradiation_effects: marked changes in precipitate structure and composition

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk11
evidence_span: Post-irradiation corrosion tests were conducted at 589, 673, and 793 K using standard techniques
corrosion_data: nodular corrosion eliminated at 793 K; uniform corrosion increased at 589 K and 673 K

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk11
evidence_span: Postirradiation annealing at 923 K/2 h caused a return of nodules to specimen edges
corrosion_data: return of nodular corrosion after annealing

extra_properties.annealing_effect: nodular corrosion returns to specimen edges

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk11
evidence_span: The corrosion rate of welded Zircaloy-4 increased rapidly at short times and then achieved a lower steady rate for longer times
corrosion_data: rapid initial increase followed by lower steady rate

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk11
evidence_span: The corrosion rate of alpha-annealed Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4 was increased relative to unirradiated material and was linear with time. The corrosion rate was roughly proportional to neutron fluence
corrosion_data: increased corrosion rate, linear with time, proportional to neutron fluence

extra_properties.fluence_dependence: corrosion rate proportional to neutron fluence

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_023_chunk11
evidence_span: Post-irradiation annealing at 923 K/2 h reduced the rate substantially, but not to the unirradiated material value
corrosion_data: corrosion rate reduced but not to unirradiated levels

extra_properties.irreversible_damage: some irradiation effects persist after annealing
